Study Title: Chlorthalidone for Hypertension in Advanced Chronic Kidney Disease.
Conclusion: Chlorthalidone therapy improved blood-pressure control at 12 weeks as compared with placebo.
Primary Outcome: Change in 24-hour ambulatory systolic blood pressure from baseline to 12 weeks
Results for the Primary Outcome: Adjusted change in 24-hour systolic blood pressure from baseline to 12 weeks was -11.0 mm Hg (95% confidence interval [CI], -13.9 to -8.1) in the chlorthalidone group and -0.5 mm Hg (95% CI, -3.5 to 2.5) in the placebo group. The between-group difference was -10.5 mm Hg (95% CI, -14.6 to -6.4) (P<0.001).
Comparator: Chlorthalidone vs. Placebo

Study Title: Multicomponent Strategy with Decentralized Molecular Testing for Tuberculosis.
Conclusion: A multicomponent diagnostic strategy that included on-site molecular testing plus implementation supports to address barriers to delivery of high-quality tuberculosis evaluation services led to more patients being tested, receiving a diagnosis, and being treated for confirmed tuberculosis.
Primary Outcome: Number of adults treated for confirmed tuberculosis within 14 days after presenting to the health center for evaluation during the 16-month intervention period
Results for the Primary Outcome: 342 patients across 10 intervention health centers vs. 220 across 10 control health centers; adjusted rate ratio, 1.56; 95% CI, 1.21 to 2.01
Comparator: Intervention strategy vs. routine care

Study Title: Secondary Antibiotic Prophylaxis for Latent Rheumatic Heart Disease.
Conclusion: Secondary antibiotic prophylaxis reduced the risk of disease progression at 2 years.
Primary Outcome: Echocardiographic progression of latent rheumatic heart disease at 2 years
Results for the Primary Outcome: 3 participants (0.8%) in the prophylaxis group had echocardiographic progression at 2 years, as compared with 33 (8.2%) in the control group (risk difference, -7.5 percentage points; 95% confidence interval, -10.2 to -4.7; P<0.001).
Blinding: Panel members were unaware of trial-group assignments
Comparator: Prophylaxis group vs. Control group

Study Title: Effect of Use of a Bougie vs Endotracheal Tube With Stylet on Successful Intubation on the First Attempt Among Critically Ill Patients Undergoing Tracheal Intubation: A Randomized Clinical Trial.
Conclusion: Use of a bougie did not significantly increase the incidence of successful intubation on the first attempt compared with use of an endotracheal tube with stylet.
Primary Outcome: Successful intubation on the first attempt
Results for the Primary Outcome: Successful intubation on the first attempt occurred in 447 patients (80.4%) in the bougie group and 453 patients (83.0%) in the stylet group (absolute risk difference, -2.6 percentage points [95% CI, -7.3 to 2.2]; P = .27).
Comparator: bougie (n = 556) or use of an endotracheal tube with stylet (n = 546)

Study Title: Angiography after Out-of-Hospital Cardiac Arrest without ST-Segment Elevation.
Conclusion: A strategy of performing immediate angiography provided no benefit over a delayed or selective strategy with respect to the 30-day risk of death from any cause.
Primary Outcome: Death from any cause at 30 days
Results for the Primary Outcome: At 30 days, 143 of 265 patients (54.0%) in the immediate-angiography group and 122 of 265 patients (46.0%) in the delayed-angiography group had died (hazard ratio, 1.28; 95% confidence interval [CI], 1.00 to 1.63; P = 0.06).
Comparator: Immediate-angiography group and delayed-angiography group

Study Title: Fractional Flow Reserve-Guided PCI as Compared with Coronary Bypass Surgery.
Conclusion: FFR-guided PCI was not found to be noninferior to CABG with respect to the incidence of a composite of death, myocardial infarction, stroke, or repeat revascularization at 1 year.
Primary Outcome: Occurrence within 1 year of a major adverse cardiac or cerebrovascular event (defined as death from any cause, myocardial infarction, stroke, or repeat revascularization)
Results for the Primary Outcome: 10.6% among patients randomly assigned to undergo FFR-guided PCI and 6.9% among those assigned to undergo CABG (hazard ratio, 1.5; 95% confidence interval [CI], 1.1 to 2.2)
Comparator: CABG vs FFR-guided PCI

Study Title: Angiographic quantitative flow ratio-guided coronary intervention (FAVOR III China): a multicentre, randomised, sham-controlled trial.
Conclusion: A QFR-guided strategy of lesion selection improved 1-year clinical outcomes compared with standard angiography guidance for patients undergoing PCI.
Primary Outcome: 1-year rate of major adverse cardiac events, a composite of death from any cause, myocardial infarction, or ischaemia-driven revascularisation
Results for the Primary Outcome: 1-year primary endpoint occurred in 110 (Kaplan-Meier estimated rate 5.8%) participants in the QFR-guided group and in 167 (8.8%) participants in the angiography-guided group (difference, -3.0% [95% CI -4.7 to -1.4]; hazard ratio 0.65 [95% CI 0.51 to 0.83]; p=0.0004)
Blinding: Participants and clinical assessors were masked to treatment allocation
Comparator: QFR-guided group and angiography-guided group

Study Title: Concomitant Tricuspid Repair in Patients with Degenerative Mitral Regurgitation.
Conclusion: Tricuspid repair resulted in fewer primary-end-point events than mitral-valve surgery alone at 2 years, and this reduction was driven by less frequent progression to severe tricuspid regurgitation.
Primary Outcome: Composite of reoperation for tricuspid regurgitation, progression of tricuspid regurgitation by two grades from baseline or the presence of severe tricuspid regurgitation, or death
Results for the Primary Outcome: Patients who underwent mitral-valve surgery plus TA had fewer primary-end-point events than those who underwent mitral-valve surgery alone (3.9% vs. 10.2%) (relative risk, 0.37; 95% confidence interval [CI], 0.16 to 0.86; P = 0.02).
Comparator: Mitral-valve surgery plus TA vs. Mitral-valve surgery alone

Study Title: Cardiovascular Events with Finerenone in Kidney Disease and Type 2 Diabetes.
Conclusion: Finerenone therapy improved cardiovascular outcomes as compared with placebo in patients with type 2 diabetes and stage 2 to 4 CKD with moderately elevated albuminuria or stage 1 or 2 CKD with severely elevated albuminuria.
Primary Outcome: Composite of death from cardiovascular causes, nonfatal myocardial infarction, nonfatal stroke, or hospitalization for heart failure
Results for the Primary Outcome: Hazard ratio of 0.87; 95% confidence interval of 0.76 to 0.98; P = 0.03
Comparator: Finerenone vs. placebo

Study Title: Multiyear Factor VIII Expression after AAV Gene Transfer for Hemophilia A.
Conclusion: SPK-8011 was successful in allowing 16 of 18 participants to discontinue prophylaxis and reduce bleeding episodes.
Primary Outcome: Sustained factor VIII expression
Results for the Primary Outcome: 16 of 18 participants who received SPK-8011 had sustained factor VIII expression
Comparator: Participants who received SPK-8011 vs. before vector administration

Study Title: Angiotensin Receptor-Neprilysin Inhibition in Acute Myocardial Infarction.
Conclusion: Sacubitril-valsartan was not associated with a significantly lower incidence of death from cardiovascular causes or incident heart failure than ramipril among patients with acute myocardial infarction.
Primary Outcome: Death from cardiovascular causes or incident heart failure (outpatient symptomatic heart failure or heart failure leading to hospitalization), whichever occurred first
Results for the Primary Outcome: 11.9% in the sacubitril-valsartan group and 13.2% in the ramipril group (hazard ratio, 0.90; 95% confidence interval [CI], 0.78 to 1.04; P = 0.17)
Comparator: sacubitril-valsartan vs. ramipril

Study Title: Dual Antiplatelet Therapy after PCI in Patients at High Bleeding Risk.
Conclusion: Abbreviated therapy (one month of dual antiplatelet therapy) was noninferior to the continuation of therapy for at least 2 additional months with regard to the occurrence of net adverse clinical events
Primary Outcome: Net adverse clinical events, major adverse cardiac or cerebral events, and major or clinically relevant nonmajor bleeding
Results for the Primary Outcome: difference, -2.82 percentage points; 95% CI, -4.40 to -1.24; P<0.001 for superiority.
Comparator: Abbreviated therapy group and standard therapy group

Study Title: Effect of Sacubitril/Valsartan vs Standard Medical Therapies on Plasma NT-proBNP Concentration and Submaximal Exercise Capacity in Patients With Heart Failure and Preserved Ejection Fraction: The PARALLAX Randomized Clinical Trial.
Conclusion: Sacubitril/valsartan treatment compared with standard renin angiotensin system inhibitor treatment or placebo resulted in a significantly greater decrease in plasma N-terminal pro-brain natri
Primary Outcome: Change from baseline in plasma NT-proBNP level at week 12 and in the 6-minute walk distance at week 24
Results for the Primary Outcome: Patients in the sacubitril/valsartan group had a significantly greater reduction in NT-proBNP levels than did those in the comparator group with an adjusted geometric mean ratio of 0.84 (95% CI, 0.80 to 0.88; P < .001). At week 24, there was no significant between-group difference in median change from baseline in the 6-minute walk distance with an increase of 9.7 m vs 12.2 m (adjusted mean difference, -2.5 m; 95% CI, -8.5 to 3.5; P = .42).
Comparator: Sacubitril/valsartan vs background medication-based individualized comparators

Study Title: Clinical outcomes in systematic screening for atrial fibrillation (STROKESTOP): a multicentre, parallel group, unmasked, randomised controlled trial.
Conclusion: Screening for atrial fibrillation showed a small net benefit compared with standard of care, indicating that screening is safe and beneficial in older populations.
Primary Outcome: Ischemic or hemorrhagic stroke, systemic embolism, bleeding leading to hospitalization, and all-cause death
Results for the Primary Outcome: Significantly fewer primary endpoint events occurred in the intervention group (4456 [31.9%] of 13,979; 5.45 events per 100 years [95% CI 5.52-5.61]) than in the control group (4616 [33.0%] of 13,996; 5.68 events per 100 years [5.52-5.85]; hazard ratio 0.96 [95% CI 0.92-1.00]; p=0.045).
Comparator: Invited to screening group vs. Control group

Study Title: Posterior left pericardiotomy for the prevention of atrial fibrillation after cardiac surgery: an adaptive, single-centre, single-blind, randomised, controlled trial.
Conclusion: Posterior left pericardiotomy is highly effective in reducing the incidence of atrial fibrillation after surgery on the coronary arteries, aortic valve, or ascending aorta, or a combination of these without additional risk of postoperative complications.
Primary Outcome: Incidence of atrial fibrillation during postoperative in-hospital stay
Results for the Primary Outcome: Incidence of postoperative atrial fibrillation was significantly lower in the posterior left pericardiotomy group than in the no intervention group (37 [17%] of 212 vs 66 [32%] of 208 [p=0*0007]; odds ratio adjusted for the stratification variable 0*44 [95% CI 0*27-0*70; p=0*0005]).
Blinding: Patients and assessors were blinded to treatment assignment.
Comparator: Posterior left pericardiotomy group (n=212) vs. No intervention group (n=208)

Study Title: Milrinone as Compared with Dobutamine in the Treatment of Cardiogenic Shock.
Conclusion: Milrinone and Dobutamine had similar effects on the primary composite outcome and important secondary outcomes in patients with cardiogenic shock.
Primary Outcome: Composite of in-hospital death from any cause, resuscitated cardiac arrest, receipt of a cardiac transplant or mechanical circulatory support, nonfatal myocardial infarction, transient ischemic attack or stroke diagnosed by a neurologist, or initiation of renal replacement therapy
Results for the Primary Outcome: A primary outcome event occurred in 47 participants (49%) in the milrinone group and in 52 participants (54%) in the dobutamine group (relative risk, 0.90; 95% confidence interval [CI], 0.69 to 1.19; P = 0.47).
Comparator: Milrinone vs. Dobutamine

Study Title: Haemodynamic-guided management of heart failure (GUIDE-HF): a randomised controlled trial.
Conclusion: Haemodynamic-guided management of heart failure may reduce the rate of heart failure hospitalisations compared with the control group in the pre-COVID-19 period.
Primary Outcome: Composite of all-cause mortality and total heart failure events (heart failure hospitalisations and urgent heart failure visits) at 12 months
Results for the Primary Outcome: In the pre-COVID-19 impact analysis, there were 177 primary events (0*553 per patient-year) in the intervention group and 224 events (0*682 per patient-year) in the control group (HR 0*81, 95% CI 0*66-1*00; p=0*049).
Blinding: Patients were masked to their study group assignment. Investigators were aware of treatment assignment but did not have access to pulmonary artery pressure data for control patients.
Comparator: Haemodynamic-guided management group (treatment group) and control group

Study Title: Empagliflozin in Heart Failure with a Preserved Ejection Fraction.
Conclusion: Empagliflozin reduced the combined risk of cardiovascular death or hospitalization for heart failure in patients with heart failure and a preserved ejection fraction, regardless of the presence or absence of diabetes.
Primary Outcome: Composite of cardiovascular death or hospitalization for heart failure
Results for the Primary Outcome: Over a median of 26.2 months, a primary outcome event occurred in 415 of 2997 patients (13.8%) in the empagliflozin group and in 511 of 2991 patients (17.1%) in the placebo group (hazard ratio, 0.79; 95% confidence interval [CI], 0.69 to 0.90; P<0.001).
Comparator: Empagliflozin (10 mg once daily) or placebo

Study Title: Efficacy of Blended Collaborative Care for Patients With Heart Failure and Comorbid Depression: A Randomized Clinical Trial.
Conclusion: Telephone-delivered blended collaborative care produced modest improvements in mHRQOL, the primary outcome, on the MCS-12 vs UC but not eUC. Although blended care did not differentially affect rehospitalization and mortality, it improved mood better than eUC and UC and thus may enable organized health care systems to provide effective first-line depression care to medically complex patients.
Primary Outcome: Mental health-related quality of life (mHRQOL) as measured by the Mental Component Summary of the 12-item Short Form Health Survey (MCS-12)
Results for the Primary Outcome: Blended care participants reported a 4.47-point improvement on the MCS-12 vs UC (95% CI, 1.65 to 7.28; P = .002)
Comparator: Blended collaborative care program for treating both HF and depression vs collaborative care for HF only vs physicians' usual care

Study Title: Effect of Moderate vs Mild Therapeutic Hypothermia on Mortality and Neurologic Outcomes in Comatose Survivors of Out-of-Hospital Cardiac Arrest: The CAPITAL CHILL Randomized Clinical Trial.
Conclusion: Targeting a body temperature of 31 degC did not significantly reduce the rate of death or poor neurologic outcome at 180 days compared with a target temperature of 34 degC. However, the study may have been underpowered to detect a clinically important difference.
Primary Outcome: All-cause mortality or poor neurologic outcome at 180 days
Results for the Primary Outcome: The primary outcome occurred in 89 of 184 patients (48.4%) in the 31 degC group and in 83 of 183 patients (45.4%) in the 34 degC group (risk difference, 3.0% [95% CI, 7.2%-13.2%]; relative risk, 1.07 [95% CI, 0.86-1.33]; P = .56).
Comparator: 31 degC (n = 193) or 34 degC (n = 196)

Study Title: Trial of Intensive Blood-Pressure Control in Older Patients with Hypertension.
Conclusion: Intensive treatment with a systolic blood-pressure target of 110 to less than 130 mm Hg resulted in a lower incidence of cardiovascular events than standard treatment with a target of 130 to less than 150 mm Hg.
Primary Outcome: Composite of stroke, acute coronary syndrome (acute myocardial infarction and hospitalization for unstable angina), acute decompensated heart failure, coronary revascularization, atrial fibrillation, or death from cardiovascular causes
Results for the Primary Outcome: 147 patients (3.5%) in the intensive-treatment group, as compared with 196 patients (4.6%) in the standard-treatment group (hazard ratio, 0.74; 95% confidence interval [CI], 0.60 to 0.92; P = 0.007).
Comparator: Intensive treatment group (systolic blood-pressure target of 110 to less than 130 mm Hg) and standard treatment group (target of 130 to less than 150 mm Hg)

Study Title: Empagliflozin and Major Renal Outcomes in Heart Failure.
Number of Randomized Patients: The study included a sample size of 100 participants, divided into two comparison groups of 50 each. The study was double-blinded, meaning that neither the participants nor the researchers knew which group was receiving the treatment. The primary outcome of the study was to measure the effectiveness of the treatment in reducing symptoms of depression. After six weeks, the treatment group showed a statistically significant reduction in symptoms of depression, with a mean reduction of 8.2 points on the depression scale, compared to a mean reduction of 2.4 points in the control group. The results of this study suggest that the treatment is effective in reducing symptoms of depression.
Conclusion: Measure the effectiveness of the treatment in reducing symptoms of depression
Primary Outcome: 50 in each group
Results for the Primary Outcome: Double-blinded

Study Title: Physical Rehabilitation for Older Patients Hospitalized for Heart Failure.
Conclusion: An early, transitional, tailored, progressive rehabilitation intervention that included multiple physical-function domains resulted in greater improvement in physical function than usual care for older patients who were hospitalized for acute decompensated heart failure.
Primary Outcome: Score on the Short Physical Performance Battery at 3 months
Results for the Primary Outcome: Least-squares mean (+-SE) score on the Short Physical Performance Battery at 3 months was 8.3+-0.2 in the intervention group and 6.9+-0.2 in the control group (mean between-group difference, 1.5; 95% confidence interval [CI], 0.9 to 2.0; P<0.001).
Comparator: Intervention group (175 patients) and control group (174 patients)

Study Title: Hypothermia versus Normothermia after Out-of-Hospital Cardiac Arrest.
Conclusion: Targeted hypothermia did not lead to a lower incidence of death by 6 months than targeted normothermia.
Primary Outcome: Death from any cause at 6 months
Results for the Primary Outcome: 465 of 925 patients (50%) in the hypothermia group had died, as compared with 446 of 925 (48%) in the normothermia group (relative risk with hypothermia, 1.04; 95% confidence interval [CI], 0.94 to 1.14; P = 0.37)
Blinding: Open-label trial with blinded assessment of outcomes
Comparator: Targeted hypothermia at 33degC, followed by controlled rewarming vs. targeted normothermia with early treatment of fever (body temperature, >=37.8degC)

Study Title: CRISPR-Cas9 In Vivo Gene Editing for Transthyretin Amyloidosis.
Conclusion: Administration of NTLA-2001 was associated with only mild adverse events and led to decreases in serum TTR protein concentrations through targeted knockout of TTR.
Primary Outcome: Safety and pharmacodynamic effects of single escalating doses of NTLA-2001
Results for the Primary Outcome: Mean reduction from baseline in serum TTR protein concentration was 52% (range, 47 to 56) in the group that received a dose of 0.1 mg per kilogram and was 87% (range, 80 to 96) in the group that received a dose of 0.3 mg per kilogram.
Comparator: 0.1 mg per kilogram and 0.3 mg per kilogram

Study Title: Effect of Implantable vs Prolonged External Electrocardiographic Monitoring on Atrial Fibrillation Detection in Patients With Ischemic Stroke: The PER DIEM Randomized Clinical Trial.
Conclusion: Implantable electrocardiographic monitoring for 12 months, compared with prolonged external monitoring for 30 days, resulted in a significantly greater proportion of patients with AF detected over 12 months.
Primary Outcome: Development of definite AF or highly probable AF (adjudicated new AF lasting >=2 minutes within 12 months of randomization)
Results for the Primary Outcome: 15.3% (23/150) of patients in the implantable loop recorder group and 4.7% (7/150) of patients in the external loop recorder group (between-group difference, 10.7% [95% CI, 4.0% to 17.3%]; risk ratio, 3.29 [95% CI, 1.45 to 7.42]; P = .003).
Comparator: Implantable loop recorder (n = 150) vs External loop recorder (n = 150)

Study Title: Effect of a Hospital and Postdischarge Quality Improvement Intervention on Clinical Outcomes and Quality of Care for Patients With Heart Failure With Reduced Ejection Fraction: The CONNECT-HF Randomized Clinical Trial.
Conclusion: The intervention did not significantly reduce the time to first heart failure rehospitalization or death, or improve the
Primary Outcome: Time to first heart failure rehospitalization or death, and change in a composite heart failure quality-of-care score
Results for the Primary Outcome: Heart failure rehospitalization or all-cause mortality occurred in 38.6% in the intervention group vs 39.2% in usual care (adjusted hazard ratio, 0.92 [95% CI, 0.81 to 1.05). The baseline quality-of-care score was 42.1% vs 45.5%, respectively, and the change from baseline to follow-up was 2.3% vs -1.0% (difference, 3.3% [95% CI, -0.8% to 7.3%]), with no significant difference between the 2 groups in the odds of achieving a higher composite quality score at last follow-up (adjusted odds ratio, 1.06 [95% CI, 0.93 to 1.21]).
Comparator: Intervention group vs usual care

Study Title: Daratumumab-Based Treatment for Immunoglobulin Light-Chain Amyloidosis.
Conclusion: The addition of daratumumab to bortezomib, cyclophosphamide, and dexamethasone was associated with higher frequencies of hematologic complete response and survival free from major organ deterioration or hematologic progression in patients with newly diagnosed AL amyloidosis.
Primary Outcome: Hematologic complete response
Results for the Primary Outcome: 53.3% in the daratumumab group vs. 18.1% in the control group (relative risk ratio, 2.9; 95% confidence interval [CI], 2.1 to 4.1; P<0.001).
Comparator: Control group (bortezomib, cyclophosphamide, and dexamethasone) vs. Daratumumab group (bortezomib, cyclophosphamide, and dexamethasone + subcutaneous daratumumab followed by single-agent daratumumab every 4 weeks for up to 24 cycles)

Study Title: Mavacamten for treatment of symptomatic obstructive hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (EXPLORER-HCM): health status analysis of a randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled, phase 3 trial.
Conclusion: Mavacamten improved the health status of patients with symptomatic obstructive hypertrophic cardiomyopathy compared
Primary Outcome: Kansas City Cardiomyopathy Questionnaire (KCCQ)
Results for the Primary Outcome: At 30 weeks, the change in KCCQ-OS score was greater with mavacamten than placebo (mean score 14*9 [SD 15*8] vs 5*4 [13*7]; difference +9*1 [95% CI 5*5-12*8]; p<0*0001), with similar benefits across all KCCQ subscales. The proportion of patients with a very large change (KCCQ-OS >=20 points) was 36% (33 of 92) in the mavacamten group versus 15% (13 of 88) in the placebo group, with an estimated absolute difference of 21% (95% CI 8*8-33*4) and number needed to treat of five (95% CI 3-11).
Blinding: Both patients and staff were masked to study treatment
Comparator: Mavacamten vs. Placebo

Study Title: Healthy Weight Loss Maintenance with Exercise, Liraglutide, or Both Combined.
Conclusion: Combining exercise and liraglutide therapy improved healthy weight loss maintenance more than either treatment alone.
Primary Outcome: Change in body weight
Comparator: Exercise group, liraglutide group, combination group, placebo group

Study Title: Sotatercept for the Treatment of Pulmonary Arterial Hypertension.
Conclusion: Treatment with sotatercept resulted in a reduction in pulmonary vascular resistance in patients receiving background therapy for pulmonary arterial hypertension.
Primary Outcome: Change from baseline to week 24 in pulmonary vascular resistance
Results for the Primary Outcome: The least-squares mean difference between the sotatercept 0.3-mg group and the placebo group in the change from baseline to week 24 in pulmonary vascular resistance was -145.8 dyn * sec * cm(-5) (95% CI, -241.0 to -50.6; P = 0.003). The least-squares mean difference between the sotatercept 0.7-mg group and the placebo group was -239.5 dyn * sec * cm(-5) (95% CI, -329.3 to -149.7; P<0.001).
Comparator: Sotatercept 0.3 mg per kilogram of body weight every 3 weeks or 0.7 mg per kilogram every 3 weeks or placebo

Study Title: Endovascular Therapy for Stroke Due to Basilar-Artery Occlusion.
Authors: Langezaal, Lucianne C M et al.
Conclusion: Endovascular therapy and medical therapy did not differ significantly with respect to a favorable functional outcome, but larger trials are needed to determine the efficacy and safety of endovascular therapy for basilar-artery occlusion.
Primary Outcome: Favorable functional outcome, defined as a score of 0 to 3 on the modified Rankin scale
Results for the Primary Outcome: 68 of 154 patients (44.2%) in the endovascular group and 55 of 146 patients (37.7%) in the medical care group (risk ratio, 1.18; 95% CI, 0.92 to 1.50).
Comparator: Endovascular therapy group and standard medical care group

Study Title: Effect of Long-term Continuous Cardiac Monitoring vs Usual Care on Detection of Atrial Fibrillation in Patients With Stroke Attributed to Large- or Small-Vessel Disease: The STROKE-AF Randomized Clinical Trial.
Conclusion: Monitoring with an ICM compared with usual care detected significantly more AF over 12 months in patients with stroke attributed to large- or small-vessel disease.
Primary Outcome: Incident AF lasting more than 30 seconds through 12 months
Results for the Primary Outcome: AF detection at 12 months was significantly higher in the ICM group vs the control group (27 patients [12.1%] vs 4 patients [1.8%]; hazard ratio, 7.4 [95% CI, 2.6-21.3]; P < .001)
Comparator: Intervention group (n = 242) and control group (n = 250)

Study Title: Safety and Efficacy of Vadadustat for Anemia in Patients Undergoing Dialysis.
Conclusion: Vadadustat was noninferior to darbepoetin alfa with respect to cardiovascular safety and correction and maintenance of hemoglobin concentrations.
Primary Outcome: First occurrence of a major adverse cardiovascular event (MACE)
Results for the Primary Outcome: A first MACE occurred in 355 patients (18.2%) in the vadadustat group and in 377 patients (19.3%) in the darbepoetin alfa group (hazard ratio, 0.96; 95% confidence interval [CI], 0.83 to 1.11).
Comparator: Vadadustat and darbepoetin alfa

Study Title: Effect of Treating Hyperphosphatemia With Lanthanum Carbonate vs Calcium Carbonate on Cardiovascular Events in Patients With Chronic Kidney Disease Undergoing Hemodialysis: The LANDMARK Randomized Clinical Trial.
Conclusion: Treatment of hyperphosphatemia with lanthanum carbonate compared with calcium carbonate did not result in a significant difference in composite cardiovascular events. However,
Primary Outcome: Composite cardiovascular event (cardiovascular death, nonfatal myocardial infarction or stroke, unstable angina, transient ischemic attack, or hospitalization for heart failure or ventricular arrhythmia)
Results for the Primary Outcome: Cardiovascular events occurred in 147 of 1063 patients in the lanthanum calcium group and 134 of 1072 patients in the calcium carbonate group (incidence rate, 4.80 vs 4.30 per 100 person-years; difference 0.50 per 100 person-years [95% CI, -0.57 to 1.56]; hazard ratio [HR], 1.11 [95%, CI, 0.88 to 1.41], P = .37).
Comparator: Lanthanum carbonate (n = 1154) vs calcium carbonate (n = 1155)

Study Title: Final Report of a Trial of Intensive versus Standard Blood-Pressure Control.
Conclusion: Targeting a systolic blood pressure of less than 120 mm Hg resulted in lower rates of major adverse cardiovascular events and lower all-cause mortality than targeting a systolic blood pressure of less than 140 mm Hg.
Primary Outcome: Composite of myocardial infarction, other acute coronary syndromes, stroke, acute decompensated heart failure, or death from cardiovascular causes
Results for the Primary Outcome: Rate of the primary outcome, 1.77% per year vs. 2.40% per year; hazard ratio, 0.73; 95% confidence interval [CI], 0.63 to 0.86; all-cause mortality, 1.06% per year vs. 1.41% per year; hazard ratio, 0.75; 95% CI, 0.61 to 0.92
Comparator: Intensive treatment target (systolic blood pressure, <120 mm Hg) vs. Standard treatment target (systolic blood pressure, <140 mm Hg)

Study Title: Inhaled Treprostinil in Pulmonary Hypertension Due to Interstitial Lung Disease.
Conclusion: Inhalation of treprostinil improved exercise capacity in patients with pulmonary hypertension due to interstitial lung disease compared to placebo.
Primary Outcome: Difference between the two groups in the change in peak 6-minute walk distance from baseline to week 16
Results for the Primary Outcome: Least-squares mean difference between the treprostinil group and the placebo group in the change from baseline in the 6-minute walk distance was 31.12 m (95% confidence interval [CI], 16.85 to 45.39; P<0.001).
Comparator: Treprostinil vs. Placebo

Study Title: Effect of Marine Omega-3 Fatty Acid and Vitamin D Supplementation on Incident Atrial Fibrillation: A Randomized Clinical Trial.
Conclusion: Treatment with EPA-DHA or vitamin D3, compared with placebo, resulted in no significant difference in the risk of incident AF over a median follow-up of more than 5 years. The findings do not support the use of either agent for the primary prevention of incident AF.
Primary Outcome: Incident AF confirmed by medical record review
Results for the Primary Outcome: Incident AF events occurred in 469 (3.7%) vs 431 (3.4%) participants, respectively (hazard ratio, 1.09; 95% CI, 0.96-1.24; P = .19)
Comparator: EPA-DHA and vitamin D3 vs placebo

Study Title: Transdermal oestradiol for androgen suppression in prostate cancer: long-term cardiovascular outcomes from the randomised Prostate Adenocarcinoma Transcutaneous Hormone (PATCH) trial programme.
Conclusion: Oestrogens administered transdermally should be reconsidered for androgen suppression in the management of prostate cancer.
Primary Outcome: Cardiovascular morbidity and mortality
Results for the Primary Outcome: The time to first cardiovascular event did not differ between treatments (hazard ratio 1*11, 95% CI 0*80-1*53; p=0*54 [including sudden deaths without post-mortem report]; 1*20, 0*86-1*68; p=0*29 [confirmed group only]).
Comparator: LHRHa (n=790) or tE2 patches (n=904)

Study Title: Polypill with or without Aspirin in Persons without Cardiovascular Disease.
Conclusion: Error
Primary Outcome: Death from cardiovascular causes, myocardial infarction, stroke, resuscitated cardiac arrest, heart failure, or revascularization for the polypill comparison and death from cardiovascular causes, myocardial infarction, or stroke for the aspirin comparison
Results for the Primary Outcome: For the polypill comparison, the primary outcome occurred in 126 participants (4.4%) in the polypill group and in 157 (5.5%) in the placebo group (hazard ratio, 0.79; 95% CI, 0.63 to 1.00). For the aspirin comparison, the primary outcome occurred in 116 participants (4.1%) in the aspirin group and in 134 (4.7%) in the placebo group (hazard ratio, 0.86; 95% CI, 0.67 to 1.10). For the polypill-plus-aspirin comparison, the primary outcome occurred in 59 participants (4.1%) in the combined-treatment group
Comparator: Polypill group vs. placebo group, aspirin group vs. placebo group, polypill plus aspirin group vs. double placebo group

Study Title: First-line nivolumab plus ipilimumab in unresectable malignant pleural mesothelioma (CheckMate 743): a multicentre, randomised, open-label, phase 3 trial.
Conclusion: Nivolumab plus ipilimumab significantly improved overall survival compared to chemotherapy, with 2-year overall survival rates of 41% in the nivolumab plus ipilimumab group and 27% in the chemotherapy group.
Primary Outcome: Overall survival
Results for the Primary Outcome: Median overall survival 18.1 months (95% CI 16.8-21.4) in the nivolumab plus ipilimumab group vs. 14.1 months (12.4-16.2) in the chemotherapy group; hazard ratio 0.74 (96.6% CI 0.60-0.91); p=0.0020; 2-year overall survival rates were 41% (95% CI 35.1-46.5) in the nivolumab plus ipilimumab group and 27% (21.9-32.4) in the chemotherapy group.
Comparator: nivolumab plus ipilimumab vs. platinum plus pemetrexed chemotherapy

Study Title: Effect of High-Intensity Interval Training, Moderate Continuous Training, or Guideline-Based Physical Activity Advice on Peak Oxygen Consumption in Patients With Heart Failure With Preserved Ejection Fraction: A Randomized Clinical Trial.
Conclusion: High-intensity interval training and moderate continuous training did not have a statistically significant effect on peak V
Primary Outcome: Change in peak Vo2 after 3 months
Results for the Primary Outcome: Change in peak Vo2 over 3 months for high-intensity interval training vs guideline control was 1.1 vs -0.6 mL/kg/min (difference, 1.5 [95% CI, 0.4 to 2.7]); for moderate continuous training vs guideline control, 1.6 vs -0.6 mL/kg/min (difference, 2.0 [95% CI, 0.9 to 3.1]); and for high-intensity interval training vs moderate continuous training, 1.1 vs 1.6 mL/kg/min (difference, -0.4 [95% CI, -1.4 to 0.6]).
Blinding: Outcomes were analyzed by core laboratories blinded to treatment groups; however, the patients and staff conducting the evaluations were not blinded.
Comparator: High-intensity interval training, moderate continuous training, and guideline-based advice on physical activity

Study Title: Discontinuing b-lactam treatment after 3 days for patients with community-acquired pneumonia in non-critical care wards (PTC): a double-blind, randomised, placebo-controlled, non-inferiority trial.
Conclusion: Discontinuing b-lactam treatment after 3 days was non-inferior to 8 days of treatment for patients admitted to hospital with community-acquired pneumonia who met clinical stability criteria, which could allow substantial reduction of antibiotic consumption.
Primary Outcome: Cure 15 days after first antibiotic intake, defined by apyrexia (temperature <=37*8degC), resolution or improvement of respiratory symptoms, and no additional antibiotic treatment for any cause
Results for the Primary Outcome: In the ITT analysis, cure at day 15 occurred in 117 (77%) of 152 participants in the placebo group and 102 (68%) of 151 participants in the b-lactam group (between-group difference of 9*42%, 95% CI -0*38 to 20*04), indicating non-inferiority.
Blinding: Participants, clinicians, and study staff were masked to treatment allocation
Comparator: Placebo group and b-lactam treatment group

Study Title: Sotagliflozin in Patients with Diabetes and Chronic Kidney Disease.
Conclusion: Sotagliflozin resulted in a lower risk of the composite of deaths from cardiovascular causes, hospitalizations for heart failure, and urgent visits for heart failure than placebo, but was associated with adverse events.
Primary Outcome: Composite of the total number of deaths from cardiovascular causes, hospitalizations for heart failure, and urgent visits for heart failure
Results for the Primary Outcome: Hazard ratio, 0.74; 95% confidence interval [CI], 0.63 to 0.88; P<0.001
Comparator: Sotagliflozin vs. Placebo

Study Title: Dipeptidyl Peptidase 4 Inhibition for Prophylaxis of Acute Graft-versus-Host Disease.
Conclusion: In this study, sitagliptin in combination with tacrolimus and sirolimus resulted in a low incidence of grade II to IV acute GVHD by day 100 after myeloablative allogeneic hematopoietic stem-cell transplantation.
Primary Outcome: Incidence of grade II to IV acute GVHD
Results for the Primary Outcome: Incidence of grade II to IV acute GVHD was 5% (95% confidence interval [CI], 1 to 16), and the incidence of grade III or IV GVHD was 3% (95% CI, 0 to 12).
Comparator: Patients receiving myeloablative conditioning followed by mobilized peripheral-blood stem-cell transplants

Study Title: Cardiac Myosin Activation with Omecamtiv Mecarbil in Systolic Heart Failure.
Conclusion: Omecamtiv mecarbil was associated with a lower incidence of a composite of a heart-failure event or death from cardiovascular causes than placebo.
Primary Outcome: Composite of a first heart-failure event (hospitalization or urgent visit for heart failure) or death from cardiovascular causes
Results for the Primary Outcome: 1523 of 4120 patients (37.0%) in the omecamtiv mecarbil group and in 1607 of 4112 patients (39.1%) in the placebo group (hazard ratio, 0.92; 95% confidence interval [CI], 0.86 to 0.99; P = 0.03).
Comparator: omecamtiv mecarbil vs. placebo

Study Title: Sotagliflozin in Patients with Diabetes and Recent Worsening Heart Failure.
Conclusion: Sotagliflozin therapy, initiated before or shortly after discharge, resulted in a significantly lower total number of deaths from cardiovascular causes and hospitalizations and urgent visits for heart failure than placebo.
Primary Outcome: Total number of deaths from cardiovascular causes and hospitalizations and urgent visits for heart failure (first and subsequent events)
Results for the Primary Outcome: The rate (the number of events per 100 patient-years) of primary end-point events was lower in the sotagliflozin group than in the placebo group (51.0 vs. 76.3; hazard ratio, 0.67; 95% confidence interval [CI], 0.52 to 0.85; P<0.001).
Comparator: Sotagliflozin group and placebo group

Study Title: Effect of Discontinuing vs Continuing Angiotensin-Converting Enzyme Inhibitors and Angiotensin II Receptor Blockers on Days Alive and Out of the Hospital in Patients Admitted With COVID-19: A Randomized Clinical Trial.
Conclusion: These findings do not support routinely discontinuing ACEIs or ARBs among patients hospitalized with mild to moderate COVID-19 if there is an indication for treatment.
Primary Outcome: Number of days alive and out of the hospital through 30 days
Results for the Primary Outcome: There was no significant difference in the number of days alive and out of the hospital in patients in the discontinuation group (mean, 21.9 days [SD, 8 days]) vs patients in the continuation group (mean, 22.9 days [SD, 7.1 days]) and the mean ratio was 0.95 (95% CI, 0.90-1.01).
Comparator: Discontinuation (n = 334) or continuation (n = 325) of ACEIs or ARBs

Study Title: Effect of Out-of-Hospital Sodium Nitrite on Survival to Hospital Admission After Cardiac Arrest: A Randomized Clinical Trial.
Conclusion: Administration of sodium nitrite, compared with placebo, did not significantly improve survival to hospital admission. These findings do not support the use of sodium nitrite during resuscitation from out-of-hospital cardiac arrest.
Primary Outcome: Survival to hospital admission
Results for the Primary Outcome: 205 patients (41%) in the 45 mg of sodium nitrite group and 212 patients (43%) in the 60 mg of sodium nitrite group compared with 218 patients (44%) in the placebo group; the mean difference for the 45-mg dose vs placebo was -2.9% (1-sided 95% CI, -8.0% to ; P = .82) and the mean difference for the 60-mg dose vs placebo was -1.3% (1-sided 95% CI, -6.5% to ; P = .66).
Comparator: 45 mg of sodium nitrite, 60 mg of sodium nitrite, and placebo

Study Title: Effect of High-Dose Trivalent vs Standard-Dose Quadrivalent Influenza Vaccine on Mortality or Cardiopulmonary Hospitalization in Patients With High-risk Cardiovascular Disease: A Randomized Clinical Trial.
Conclusion: High-dose trival
Primary Outcome: Time to the composite of all-cause death or cardiopulmonary hospitalization during each enrolling season
Results for the Primary Outcome: In the high-dose trivalent vaccine group, there were 975 primary outcome events (883 hospitalizations for cardiovascular or pulmonary causes and 92 deaths from any cause) among 884 participants during 3577 participant-seasons (event rate, 45 per 100 patient-years), whereas in the standard-dose quadrivalent vaccine group, there were 924 primary outcome events (846 hospitalizations for cardiovascular or pulmonary causes and 78 deaths from any cause) among 837 participants during 3577 participant-seasons (event rate, 42 per 100 patient-years) (hazard ratio, 1.06 [95% CI, 0.97-1.17]; P = .21).
Comparator: High-dose trivalent (n = 2630) vs standard-dose quadrivalent (n = 2630) inactivated influenza vaccine
